 I could have seriously just eaten these as my meal.The goat ropa was excellent as well.  The goat meat is shredded in a way that resembled pulled pork.  It was served with goat cheese and grilled baguette pieces.  The goat was absolutely delicious and was cooked perfectly.  The tangy and creaminess of the goat cheese were nice additions to the meat.  I liked mixing it all together and topping the baguette pieces with it.  However, there could have been more baguette pieces served along with the meat.  We had to request more bread so we could finish it.The lamb meatballs were OK, but definitely not anything to write home about.  I really didn't enjoy the way that they were prepared.  It was served with a sherry foie cream and peas.  I didn't care for the sherry.Next, our server brought out the salad, which comprised of Catalan spinach, currants, pine nuts and thinly shaved green apple pieces.  I really wish that he would have served us the salad first instead since my stomach was already very full of meat.  The flavors were good, but the portions were too large.Last we had the diver scallops, which I didn't enjoy.  It was served with some sort of basil and pesto sauce.  I thought there was just too much sauce on them.  They were cooked well, but the sauce ruined it for me.For dessert, we shared the ice cream and sorbet trio.  We tried the pink peppercorn strawberry, vanilla peach and blueberry creme fraiche.  You must try the blueberry creme fraiche!  I wanted to ask if I could take a pint of it home to go!  It was creamy and tangy with a nice hint of sweetness from the blueberries.  The pink peppercorn strawberry was good, but it could have used more peppercorn.  The vanilla peach was a solid ice cream, but nothing out of the ordinary.Service was fine, but he didn't check up on us much.  I think that would have been different had we each did the tasting menu ($65 per person).  The ambiance was just OK as well.  It definitely was not as lively as other tapas restaurants that I have been to.  Maybe this was because we dined on a Sunday night, but nevertheless.  It was way more mellow and subdued.Overall, I'm glad that I got a chance to visit and eat at an Iron Chef's restaurant.  But, I don't see myself rushing back any time soon due to the small portions and the high prices.

Reviews.Author: Magen R.
Reviews.Content: Wasn't a huge fan of this place.I came here a few months ago for brunch with some friends and it did not live up to the hype. The included meat, cheese and dessert table was disappointing at best. There was only one kind of meat... pretty pathetic if you ask me. There were also no crackers to put any of your meat and cheese on. Kinda strange. The several courses of brunch were just so so. There were a few standout items like the bacon wrapped dates but on the whole it was pretty meh and definitely not worth the price.I'd definitely come back to try the tapas at night so I could pick and choose though. Maybe I'll be amending this review someday...

Reviews.Author: Mel Z.
Reviews.Content: No wait for brunch on memorial day weekend. It's nice but then also alarming. Got seated very quickly and our waiter was nice. However, they got all of our orders wrong. I ordered my steak medium rare and my friend ordered medium. When the dish came, they just assumed that he got the medium rare and I got the medium. When I asked them how mine was done, they said medium well and that my friend had medium....errr. Very irritating.The dish were OK. The ingredients were fresh but my steak was wayyyy too salty. Could not finish the dish. The soup I ordered was quite unmemorable. Overall, a very underwhelming experience.

Reviews.Author: Victoria G.
Reviews.Content: I have heard about this place so many times and finally this one cold winter night we went there to celebrate special occasion. It was a wonderful experience. They kept bringing food... more and more (we ordered tasting menu with wine). But every bite was simply delicious. I was surprized that desert was not included in the tasting menu but we ordered separately. the cheesecake with some fancy sauce and berries was melting in my mouse. Definitely would love to go back one day again.

Reviews.Author: Allison M.
Reviews.Content: I came here on Passover, so I was extremely limited in the things I could eat.  All I had was the espinaca a la catalana, and it was so great!  Garlicky and savory and sweet and piping hot.The decor and the atmosphere here is so warm and welcoming.  Easily one of the most inviting restaurants I've been in.  Can't wait to come back and try some of the dishes with leavening, or one of their fancy cocktails!

Reviews.Author: Jeni P.
Reviews.Content: Fabulous place to eat. Love the atmosphere, the food, everything.  Bit on the pricy side ($200 for 4 people) and it's definitely not a place where you go if you're in a hurry (1:30 hrs to eat).  But overall a great, relaxing evening out for dinner.

Reviews.Author: Shereene M.
Reviews.Content: I am OBSEESSED with this place! I literally love love love it! We entered on the Michigan Ave entrance where you walk into a cute little lounge that would be cool to chill in. Then we walked upstairs and was wow'ed! It is so much bigger than you expect. It is seriously the prettiest restaurant I have ever been to. It's beautiful! The décor is really pretty, but my only complaint is the tables are pretty tight. If you are wearing a jacket/coat, check it! Also, the bathroom is in the hotel that is attached but that wasn't a big deal to walk to.So I went with one girlfriend, so we shared a bunch of items and were STUFFED to the MAX. We got drinks, but I honestly can't even remember what we got. The food is amazing! The portions are small so I wouldn't go with more than a group of 4. Our waiter was a guy with curly hair. He was super animated and used his hands a lot. He was very knowledgeable and helpful when we needed recommendations. I wish I remembered his name! This is what we ordered:Goat cheese with shredded goat with bread- really yummy if you like goat cheeseBacon wrapped dates- good but super smallCalamari- was expecting fried but was still very good, the sauce is delish!Lamb lollypops- the star of the show! You must get it!!Dessert- so we knew we had to get dessert even though we were going to burst. Our amazing waiter recommended this dish not on the menu but is on the "tasting menu" which is a small bite of something hot and something cold. Get it if you want something sweet but not huge. All I remember was two delicious bites and horchata ice cream being involved!!Bill came to $120 I believe with tip.. not bad!I can't wait to go back!! I made a reservation right on Yelp the night of, but it was really busy on a Thursday night. It's super cute but we were casual, and felt like it was ok.

Reviews.Author: Jules H.
Reviews.Content: Came here for a late Sunday brunch after a trip to the Chicago Art Institute. Low key casual roomy place. Greeted promptly and led to a nice corner table. After a helpful explanation of their Sunday brunch menu, the egg tapas and other treats starting arriving.Sunday brunch is a prix fixe menu of $25 with 3 courses of well made small plates, and a small but nice Charcuterie buffet that included cheeses and desserts. Everything tasted great, we really liked the bacon wrapped dates and beet salad. My fellow diner had a top notch self serve bloody mary. One thing that was a little off and disappointing was the lack of plate clearing. Service was polite, but we had to keep stacking our used tapas plates onto the empty table next to ours. I hate busing my own table when I'm paying $50 for brunch. Our waiter would disappear for 20 minutes at a time. But then he'd come back with another round of tasty tapas plates, and all was forgiven. Really great food, nice bloody mary bar too.

Reviews.Author: Eric Y.
Reviews.Content: We had dinner with a group of 8.  We got to sit at the large antique table in the center of the restaurant; the one with the regal-looking high backed chairs.  We felt special even though the chairs were not the most comfortable!Our meal was delicious.  We ordered a variety of tapas.  Highlights included the bacon-wrapped dates stuffed with an almond.  The grilled baby octopus is outstanding.  The foie-rabbit rillette on toast with quince paste was delicious.  Blood sausage - earthy, salty and grilled to perfection.  We were disappointed by the jamon iberico - it was not up the deliciousness that we've come to expect from this rare product.  The sauteed peppers are tasty but don't need the sauce that comes with them.Highly recommended!

Reviews.Author: Samantha K.
Reviews.Content: OK. I lived in Barcelona and this is by far one of the BEST tapas places in Chicago. Not only is the decor scream Catalonia and inspired greatly by Barca and all of its nuances but the food is done in such a delicious and upscale way. My best friend and I went here about 3 years ago after my college graduation. We enjoyed many tapas. A few jarras of sangria which they have a seasonal on barrel and several different red and whites too. I have not been back to Mercator a la Planxa YET, but I have not stopped talking about how blown away I was with the food decor and staff. I plan on getting back in there very soon to see if what I experienced 3 years ago still holds true.

Reviews.Author: Christine S.
Reviews.Content: I had extremely poor service at Mercat a la Plaxa. While I usually don't like to do this, I spoke with the manager who took a few cocktails off our bill, which was greatly appreciated.The food was fine, but definitely not worth the price point.I will not be going back and definitely not recommend spending the money here.

Reviews.Author: Erika K.
Reviews.Content: January is acting a fool this year, providing you with all the more reason to treat yourself to a warming meal during Restaurant Week in Chicago. There's nothing quite like braving negative wind chills to gorge on tapas that are much more appropriate for warmer weather. It's as close we're getting to a vacation. I tend to feel skeptical towards tapas: they're so tiny that you're smart to arrive with a semi-full stomach and aren't there always a couple of blah dishes? Not at Mercat, where nearly every course is fresh and flavorful--and you almost leave full!Full review and pictures at: thebuckwheater.com/merca…

Reviews.Author: Ian L.
Reviews.Content: in the south loop, a nice, upscale restaurant with an excellent view. the views of millenium park are amazing.the only downside is the small portions (common at these tapas places). Spend 50 per pax before drinks.We had the:monte enebro / goat's milkpear & saffron compoteThey were well executed, but nothing really stood out.foie amb conill rabbit and foie gras rillette, truffle lavender quince. The foie gras was phenomenal, and we would definitely recommend this.dátiles con almendras and bacon-wrapped dates stuffed with almonds. ahh, one of the highlights. sure many tapas places do this as well, however these were perfectly executed, and came with some costillas de ternera and beef shortribs, horseradish, parmesan & bacon marmalade.good, the serving of shortribs was miniscule. still it was sufficient to whet our appetite. escalivada d'alberginia and eggplant fritters with roasted red peppers, tomatoes and cipollinis, goat cheese and lavender honey. Excellent. the hint of lavender honey balances and enhances the otherwise too salty eggplants. all in all, it could work better as an appetizer. ended with morcillatraditional catalán blood sausage, spainGood first experience with catalan blood sausage, a must try.

Reviews.Author: Comensal A.
Reviews.Content: I had wanted to try Mercat for quite some time, but had been put off by the prices. Recently, I threw frugality to the winds and paid a visit. Sorry to say I was disappointed -- the place just didn't deliver value commensurate with the prices.We ordered the $65 tasting menu so we could sample a variety of dishes. On the plus side, there was plenty of food. A few of the dishes we sampled were OK, but none really stood out, with the exception of bacon-wrapped dates, which were quite nicely done. Octopus was tasty enough, but a little tougher than it needed to be. A salami plate and a cheese plate were enjoyable. Prawns had a faint ammonia character (as happens all to often). A steak plate was flavorful, but very gristly. The vaunted spinach with currants & apple was much too salty. (Saltiness was in fact a theme, as can be the case at Spanish restaurants.) Patatas bravas was nicely presented, and tasted fine.Drinkwise, I had the wine pairing, and was underwhelmed by the quality (my suggestion: start with a glass of nice garnacha, then have a glass of tempranillo). There is a fairly comprehensive selection of Spanish wines by the bottle, but they seem a bit pricey -- based on my experience buying Spanish wine at retail, there ought to be a few decent bottles of garnacha and tempranillo in the mid-$30s, not the mid-$40s.Service was admirable in one respect: pacing -- our courses came in a timely fashion and we got out in time to make a show without rushing. The plate runners were courteous, but spoke so quickly that we couldn't really understand what they were presenting. The bussers were similarly courteous. The main server did a decent job of introducing us to the menu, but seemed rushed & brisk.The ambiance was not to my taste. We were fortunate to have a four-top table -- if we had been at one of the tiny two-tops, it would have been miserable trying to fit all the dishes on the table. The noise level was OK when we arrived, but built throughout our visit to the point where trying to converse was unpleasant by the time we left.The whole experience reinforced for me why I'm about done with hotel restaurants: overpriced, so-so food, unrelaxing ambiance, rushed service and an overall "food factory" feel. There are Spanish dining options in the city that deliver much better overall value, and I'll go to them when I want a tapas fix.

Reviews.Author: Laura A.
Reviews.Content: This place is pricey, but the food is so worth it. I first came for restaurant week and tried one of the flatbreads - delicious! The next time I came was for tapas - the bacon wrapped dates were fabulous and the sangria was really good.

Reviews.Author: Amy R.
Reviews.Content: Mercat tries to WOW! you with the plate presentation but fails to deliver on taste and portion size (for the prices charged).  Our party of 4 enjoyed the ambiance and service of Mercat but decided to stop eating when we realized we were never going to get full on the extremely small portions being served.Our samples (and I do mean "samples" because the portions are SO SMALL) included:- Olives:  the only decent sized portion served to us all night.  It's a good variety of olives.- Pimentos se Padron:  this is an impressive tapa, and also one of the few decent sized portions served.  Very good!- Gambas y Chorizo Flatbread:  This could have been a slice of pepperoni pizza and we would not have known the difference.  The ingredients all just blended together into something really boring.  And it is so small that saying a "slice" accurately describes this underwhelming and tiny flatbread (at $14).  - Costillas de Ternera Flatbread:  Again, the flavors that enticed us from the menu description just blended together on this "slice" and it was like some shredded BBQ on a tiny piece of bread.- Mixto Croquetas:  this is definitely the smallest croqueta I've ever been served.  It was fine but one person would need their own plate to really get a taste of it.- Datiles con Almendras:  Four dates for $9 which meant one per person at our table which was not enough to even really taste it.  The plate served to us was more greens than dates, and they cleared it from the table before the greens could be eaten.- Patatas Bravas:  The biggest disappointment of the night because the plate is just 7 little thimble-sized potatoes with a squirt of sauce.  No spice, no flavor, and very little potato!  HUGE DISAPPOINTMENT for one of my all-time favorite tapas.- Garrotxa:  three tiny pieces of cheese, some thin apple slices, and some bread with a small portion of bland sauce - BORINGI might try this place again, but I would not want to eat with a crowd because these plates aren't meant to be shared by more than 2.  And then that pretty much defeats the point in enjoying tapas with friends.  We left feeling hungry, underwhelmed and robbed.

Reviews.Author: Andrea B.
Reviews.Content: This place was one of the best spanish places I've tried. I love tapas, and mercat was everything I hoped for. I wish we would've done the chef's tasting, but it was a little on the expensive side, so we stuck to choosing our own tapas. The potatoes were the best thing I got. The bacon wrapped dates were also amazing. The place was upscape and trendy but the staff was a bit snooty. Would definitely go here again.

Reviews.Author: Kim N.
Reviews.Content: Being right next to my hotel, this was the last meal before leaving Chicago for home. We ended up going right as they opened for dinner. Not my usual time for eating but since I was going to be on a 5 hour plane ride, I didnt want to be clamoring for plane food on the way back. We met Jenn our server and told her of our time crunch. The space is large and beautiful. Very open dining room and kitchen. As we sat down a bunch of people with name tags started filling in the spaces. Must be convention time?We got some recommendations from Jenn and ended up with:PULPO CON PATATASSpanish Octopus, Confit Potato, Smoked PaprikaGAMBAS AL AJILLOGarlic Shrimppintxos muranosColorado Lamb Brochettes wrapped in Bacon, Lamb JusBOQUERONESWhite Anchovies with Pine Nuts, Olive & Anaheim PeppersALBONDIGAS DE CORDEROLamb Meatballs, Sherry Foie Cream, PeasROPA DE CABRAKilgus Farms Goat Ropa with Goat Cheese and Grilled BaguetteArroz a la CazuelaSaffron Scented Broth with Maine Lobster, Chicken, Chorizo, Rabbit, Shaved Artichoke Salad & Piquillo AioliVarious cured meats:FERMIN JAMÓN IBÉRICO DE BELLOTAFERMIN LOMO EMBUCHADOJAMÓN DE PATOBUTIFARRA CATALANASome of this certainly brought back memories of Spain, though the execution is obviously American influenced. Jenn took really good care of us and basically got us out of there in an hour. Looking at the full menu there are so many things I still want to try. Tapas is just not enough.

Reviews.Author: Anne F.
Reviews.Content: Went here for date night. The night was really slow (surprising for a Saturday), so we were seated right away even though we didn't have a reservation. Highlights were the sangria, bacon-wrapped dates (yum!!!), rabbit pasta (yum!!), lamb meatballs, short rib flatbread, and the salmon. Not so much of a fan of the spicy potatoes (kind of dry). Dessert was delicious as well. Our server was kind of non-existent at first, but she got better throughout the evening (probably had more time for us once some of her tables left). Overall, I would definitely return, though it is a bit overpriced. I can think of equally good restaurants that are significantly less expensive.

Reviews.Author: Mandi G.
Reviews.Content: This was my favorite brunch spot in the city. However, they no longer do bottomless mimosas/sangria/bloody Marys. It is now $5 per drink. So what used to be a $33 brunch has now turned into a $50+ brunch.The food and service were still great. If you are not a total lush like myself, this is a nice place to do more upscale brunches and they do have a separate seating area if you have a large group.Please, please, please bring back the bottomless drink option. It breaks my heart to have to take you off my brunch list.

Reviews.Author: Alison Y.
Reviews.Content: I was really looking forward to eating here ever since I ate at Chifa, in Philadelphia, another Jose Garces restaurant. We came here for lunch since my brotehr recommended it and told us they had a cheap lunch option. The Catalan Express allows you to choose an appetizer and entree plus a fountain drink for 18 dollars. I chose the serrano and chorizo croquettes and the hange steak. The hubby chose arroz a la cazuela and the salmon. The arroz was really, really good and the croquettes were fine. My steak with potato croquette though was really, really greasy. So much so that I couldn't finish it and that's saying a lot. The serving was not even that big. The service left much to be desired as well. There were only two tables at tha hour, but I found the waiters inattentive.Although the food wasn't too expensive I was expecting a lot more. Will not be back.

Reviews.Author: Seth F.
Reviews.Content: The Serrano Ham and Fig Salad and Bacon Wrapped Dates were good, but honestly I'm pretty sure an instance of bacon wrapped dates not being good is a sure-fire sign of The Apocalypse, so I'm gonna use this little time we have together to talk about an issue that's very important to me: the ordering of an entire animal at a restaurant.The last time I was here, we ordered a pig for a friend's 30th birthday.  Now I know that sounds like a great idea on paper, and G-d knows there are few more effective ways to firmly establish yourself on the top of the food chain, but take it from someone who has walked this path too many times, it's ALWAYS a better idea in theory than in practice.  When you order an entire animal at a restaurant you make the chef focus on the arduous task of cooking a very large thing, and not the act of making the meat that you get from that animal taste as delicious as possible.  This has been true every time I've done this, from multiple times at Frontier, to getting a goat leg at Girl and The Goat, and here.  Seriously: just don't do it.  Thank you for listening to this very important public service announcement.

Reviews.Author: Layne S.
Reviews.Content: Good food yet expensive.  Highlights were the rib eye and the bacon wrapped lamb. Didn't really like the fried peppers or the cinnamon dessert. It's a good place to go for a special occasion yet there are better places for me to go when spending $250 without alcohol...  Last visit made me learn I'd rather go to a nice steakhouse or Shaws...

Reviews.Author: Niraj G.
Reviews.Content: Went for lunch and had the fried peppers, spanish omelette, wild mushroom soup, wild mushroom flatbread, and patatas fritas.  Food was excellent, especially the soup as it had nice hints of truffle.  Heard the dinner menu was even better so we'll definitely be checking that out.

Reviews.Author: Jason S.
Reviews.Content: Pretty nice joint!Came here for a post-wedding dinner.  Didn't really get to try the food to start, but that was OK, I had plenty of time to cozy up to a vat of sangria. Sangria?!? Sangria you ask incredulously?  No, no, not Riunite Lambrusco and Sprite with sliced oranges.  Imagine a wooden barrel of delicious fruits paired perfectly with the appropriate wines and then add, wait for it... brandy.  Oh yeah, that just happened.So, after swimming in the limitless supply of three different varieties of boozy punch, they could have served me anything afterwards and I would have loved it.  Good thing their food is amazing too.  I was stuck with the selection that was pre-set for the party, would have loved to venture out and hit the menu on a non-party night.Not sure about the whole Iron Chef thing, don't really follow the whole celebrity/tv chef thing, but this place is solid.

Reviews.Author: Erica P.
Reviews.Content: We had an absolutely amazing time here, went 5pm on a Friday night for an early dinner/happy hour.Great service, food was absolutely amazing, there wasn't anything that we tried that we didn't like, and we ordered 10 dishes.Highlights:White sangria, tastes like water with fruit, goes down way too easyGarlic ShrimpMeat and Cheese SelectionCroquetasJamonSpanish OmeletteList goes on...Check it out, this place is fantastic, highly recommend!

Reviews.Author: Tommaso S.
Reviews.Content: The Experience was perfect! Paella the best I have ever had since Spain. Gracias chef !

Reviews.Author: Rosa N.
Reviews.Content: I have been to this place twice and it was very good each time.  Bacon wrapped dates, cheese platter, short ribs, mushroom risotto....you name it is was good!   Now the warning here is on the calamari.  It is grilled.  That is no bueno for me.

Reviews.Author: Diana R.
Reviews.Content: Came here on a weekend, the food was good but the service needed work, our waitress was hard to find and disappeared for most of our meal.  I tried to get a refill of drinks but the service was nowhere to found.  I had one of their cocktails about a month ago and it was good so naturally I wanted another one, it was called the sombra or sombrero, at $13, it's a little pricey but its downtown prices. what can you expect?  Overall, they need work on their service, they have a good product. The empanada with spinach was really great!

Reviews.Author: Bob H.
Reviews.Content: In Chicago for a conference. We enjoyed it so much, we returned two nights later with friends. The tapas were excellent and varied. The spinach and fig salad wrapped with jamon was delicious, the lamb rib chops with romescu and octopus were both really enjoyable.  The wine list featured Spanish wines and were reasonably priced.I would recommend it to anyone traveling to Chicago looking for Spanish cuisine with   a flare.

Reviews.Author: Christine K.
Reviews.Content: Came with a fairly large and shared a couple dishes.  I did some research before going and ordered for us:all 3 types of the flatbreadsetas al horno paella valenciana patatas bravas (2)jamon de patobacon wrapped dates (2)dessert croquettesI wanted to try the sobrasada y boqueron coca, but one of my friends who was sitting next to me (and with whom I was sharing the coca) wanted to try the braised short ribs one instead. Sigh, she's such a fastidious eater, so I was disappointed to have to forego the sobrasada y boqueron coca.  Everyone seemed to enjoy the paella, jamon de pato, and setas al horno the most.  Mercat definitely prepares its setas al horno dish differently from other tapas places, but it's the positive type of creativity in the food.  I will come, again, to try the butternut squash dumplings, arroz de coliflor, mar i muntanya, and lunch menu.  The ambience and interior decor are perfect for dates or gatherings with friends.  Make sure to reserve your seating early on if you have a group.  Otherwise, you'll have to wait a bit.

Reviews.Author: Leslie H.
Reviews.Content: Great service. Great atmosphere. Great food.Went here for lunch and was pleasantly surprised with the chef's tasting menu. My hubby and I had shared about 7-8 courses and it was priced at $30/pp. The food was incredibly good. My hubby absolutely loved the flights of sangria as well.

Reviews.Author: Eric M.
Reviews.Content: I wasn't blown away by this place.  The atmosphere is less "tapas bar" and more "Vegas" style with large, multi level stations, not warm, not food-centric and "programmed" presentations by the waiters who I gather, have not been to Spain based on their non-answers to my specific questions about the food and wine.  The food was "good", not great, and the fact that we were stuffed in a corner, at an odd shaped table for an important business dinner, told me the host had a tin ear when it came to the seating and comfort of guests. Finally- the olive oil ice cream was a big disappointment. I raved about the wonder of this dessert to my table mates and it was a tasteless, powdery lump. I order olive oil ice cream whenever I see it, it's an "index" dish that tells me a lot about a place. I recommend they remove it from the menu.....

Reviews.Author: Fei W.
Reviews.Content: Just tried this place with a friend.  We had:-Lamb meatballs-Spanish omelette-Anchovies-Lamb curry-Horchata bon bonsThe lamb curry was the best, but everything was way too salty... except ironically, the anchovies.  They were the least salty and our least favorite.  I think maybe we didn't know what to expect, but they were just served on olive oil with some pine nuts and the texture and taste were not great.The horchata bon bons were a great finish though.  Overall, I think Cafe Iberico is a much better value.

Reviews.Author: Tawnya P.
Reviews.Content: Food: every single thing was fabulous. Bacon wrapped dates a signature for a reason. Cheese selections delicious. Lamb pops magnificent and moist and terrific sauce selections.The only thing I didn't give this another star for is that you have to know going into it that you're not able to pick anything off the menu unless you're prepared to stay for a long, long, time. I wanted a short rib dish that takes 90 minutes to prepare, so if we wanted to have a less than all-evening event, we had limited choices. There are plenty to choose from, just perhaps not what your heart may desire, if it takes too long to cook!

Reviews.Author: Alex K.
Reviews.Content: If you like tasty tapas, an open and inviting atmosphere, and hexagon-inspired decorations, Mercat a la Planxa is the place for you!As basically everyone else here has said, the bacon-wrapped dates are incredible. Strangely enough, my first bite tasted like the most delicious corn dog I could ever imagine.The variety of flavors across all of the dishes was probably the most impressive part of the meal. Every bite of every plate offered up something new and exciting.Our waitress was very helpful in navigating the menu. And the complimentary dessert she foisted upon us despite our protests ended up being delicious as well, and a perfect way to finish off the meal.

Reviews.Author: Harpreet K.
Reviews.Content: Because I'm a hater, I must first note that there were a few WTF's up in here. First and foremost, one of my pet peeves is walking into a restaurant with 15 ornamental staffers hangin out and still waiting ten minutes for a menu. Get to steppin' folks, I'm here to eat. Second, what up with all the wireless headsets? The restaurant was half empty at 6pm on Sunday but there were still a lot of frantic "emergency" sitchos being handled via walky-talkies, with nary a celebrity in sight. Kinda diva. Plus, earpieces are so Whitney in The Bodyguard. And we all know Whitney is an I-don't-do-crackhead.Because I'm also a lover, let's move onto the good. The specialty drink menu was fantastic; really refreshing, fruity drinks with HEAVY POURS. I was knocked the f*ck out after one, and I'm 6' 2" (with a booty) motherf*ckers!! I had the Shoco Cocktail (peach vodka, fresh sour, OJ, cucumber and sage leaves), and my friend had the Merengue (fresh strawberries, lime and passion fruit puree, grapefruit vodka). Mine was good, hers was insane. We shared a couple tapas because we were just there to sample the goods; specifically, the Higo Con Almendres (bacon-wrapped figs stuffed with almonds) and Alcachotas y Seta flatbread (artichoke and wild mushrooms, black truffles, and manchego). The dates were wonderful, if a little small. Perfectly crisp, salty, chewy bacon wrapped around warm, sweet, soft figs. The flatbread though, HOT DAMN, where you came from?! Hearty, heady flavors; the vibrancy of a strong spanish cheese with truffles, with light hints of lemon to offset the richness. It was make-your-night delicious.Do it.

Reviews.Author: Caroline A.
Reviews.Content: I finally got back to Mercat, nine months after a mediocre experience, and enjoyed it. I was with two of my besties, and we had a fantastic night of delicious food, cocktails and laughs. I still think it lacks a certain level of refinement, but I enjoyed the energy and crowd on a Thursday night.We did the chef's tasting, and while it was way too much food for me, it was very good. We had:Serrano Ham & Fig SaladCana de Cabra - Goats Milk and Balsamic Strawberries - This was fantastic. I could not stop eating the balsamic strawberry spread.The beef shortrib flatbread - How could you go wrong?? It was beefy, cheesy deliciousness.Garlic Shrimp - VERY GARLICEY - You do not want to eat this if you are on a date. Jumbo PrawnsSeafood Ceviche - This was probably my favorite. It was light and refreshing.Rabbit Ravioli Lamb - This was probably my second favorite. It came out pretty rare, tender and flavorful. For dessert, we had the chocolate croquettes with banana marshmallows. It was definitely something to try, but a bit disappointing. The three of us were not satisfied, so we got ice cream. :) The drink menu was good... but what do I know? I got drunk on half a glass of wine. Service was a little slow, but not bad. The lighting is excellent.

Reviews.Author: Swatee G.
Reviews.Content: Brace yourself for a long review dear reader, I am an angry young woman, and I shall YELP to vent!Yelp Disappointment PERIODThe ambiance is good, the service was the worst I have ever experienced and the food just blatantly overpriced, over hyped and useless! So we walk in, with reservations. I am impressed by the decor and  the size of the place! I have heard good things from Yelp, and I am excited about trying this place.So our hostess walks us over to a TINNNNEEEEEE, believe me TINEEE table in a corner for two people, so much so that my friends and i have touching knees ( not cool ), and worst so, the couple right next to us are right in our face too! We are embarrassed, they are embarrassed, I mean there is no way enough space for 4 people, and we don't know what to say! The hostess has mysteriously disappeared, we wait for our server to appear. 5 minutes wait, server comes.. could we have a different table please? No.. we are full up. Umm... I see some tables empty right there. We..eell, those are reserved! ok.. I gave up! Uncomfortable as we were by this breach of personal space, I was not going to let it ruin my soon to begin superior culinary experience. Well, I am about to be disappointed!! I will begin with the best-Complimentary Tomato Flatbread- Maybe they should make this a menu dish. It was really good!Verdosa Mixed Greens with Green Asparagus, Avocado, Confit Cherry Tomatoes & Shaved Mahon Cheese- The only highlight of my so called culinary experience. I would have it again.Spanish Omelette with Spinach,Potatoes & Saffron Aioli - Would be a decent dish, maybe, had it got Salt in it!Patatas Bravas Spicy Potatoes with Spicy Paprika Aioli- PLEASE dont call this a dish! It is a side.. and a poor man's over hyped, over priced one at that!Catalan Spinach, Raisins, Pine Nuts & Apples - umm.. blanched spinach stacked with green apples is NOT an appetizing dish,.. you DO NOT have to be Gordon Ramsey to realize that please!Arroz a la Cazuela Saffron Scented Broth with Maine Lobster, Chicken,Chorizo, Rabbit, Shaved Artichoke Salad & Piquillo Aioli- By far the ugliest, and most tasteless dish I have ever eaten! It was like they dumped all left overs together and brought it to us in a bowl, with a n enormous price tag. Please please avoid this dish.I don;t even want to talk of the desserts now.. sigh.. I have a terrible memory of the horrors! I will never ever go here again!But I must say the service sucked! We had the two dishes on our tinee table,a nd the server unceremoniously dumps another one, then one more.. and now there is no place for the 5th.. please can we finish one at a time?!The server appeared ONLY when we had waited atleast 10 minutes each time for him to grace us with his presence, never explained any dish and was just blatantly unconcerned. And with this, I cannot go on any more,... I hated the place..and ohhhh... the Seasonal Sangria.. have it only if you LOVE Cinnamon.. thats all it has! And the Margarita with cucumbers, BITTER!!!!sigh.. now I am done venting!

Reviews.Author: Nick M.
Reviews.Content: **** This is a MUST experience for food lovers on Yelp ***** Uh... where to begin... Mercat's food hits your taste buds like a falcon punch to the groin or an Amy kick to your nuts (women = pajengo, or whoo ha), it's a slap to the face, twist the nipple fantastic (Warning... This was a dramatisation PLEASE do NOT perform any of these acts to myself or others). This Tapas Catalan inspired menu is over whelming at first but after a dish or two plus some of their tasty Red Sangria you'll be a pro, rolling your "Rrrrrrr"'s and everything. Also prices can be a little deceiving but after all is said and bellies are full, it's really not that bad. My recommendations Verdosa -Mixed Baby Greens with Green Asparagus, Avocado,Confit Cherry Tomatoes & Shaved Mahon Cheese. Pimientos De Padron -Fried Peppers, Salbitxada & Sea Salt. Gambas Al Ajillo -Garlic Shrimp. Arroz Can Morels -Morel Mushroom Bomba Rice, Green Asparagus & Lemon Oil. Cepes Y Butifarra -Porcini & Catalan Sausage, Roasted Garlic and Manchego. Patatas Bravas -Spicy Potatoes with Spicy Paprika Aioli. And for desert that has beaten ALL of my other desserts... EVER (Probably going to lose my man card again but this dessert made me close my eyes) Croquetas de Xocolata -Milk Chocolate Croquettes, Banana Marshmallow, Rosemary Carmel, Arbequina Olive Oil. Each plate design was colorful and creative as the next. Great use of scale not only in food design but the decor of the restaurant itself. Even not for the food the service was exceptional and or waiter recommended half of what we ate. The staff really make you feel welcome and important. I really want to go back for the chiefs selection, he plans your whole menu and they have an option to include a wine or beer pairing with the dishes. I'm only upset that I've just now discovered this vision of Barcelona for the senses. I don't normal say this but I would give Mercat a la Planxa 10 stars if I could.

Reviews.Author: Ryan L.
Reviews.Content: I am not a big fan of tapas as i am always left pretty hungry and this was no exception.  I had friends visiting and after tearing into some sausage from Hot Doug's earlier, they decided tapas was a good idea.  I heard good things from friends, but I was very disappointed in my meal.  Food was good, sometimes great, but not enough moments of greatness.  Service was seriously lacking.  It was a busy night, but doesn't give them a pass for the sometimes lousy service.When we arrived we were told there was a 45 minute wait.  No problem, my friends wanted to sit in the lounge anyways because it was more private and secluded.  Sure enough, it was so secluded a server never showed up.  We waited 20 minutes and asked twice for a server but got nothing.  My friend got up and asked the hostess, who was very gracious and apologized, and then suddenly a table was open for us in the main area.  Funny how this works.Other comments about the flatbreads are right, they are very good.  The porcini and catalan sausage was quite tasty.  Other selections -braised rabbit pasta - i think this was my favorite in terms of flavor, but the portion was smallslow-cooked shortribs and diver scallops - i was disappointed in this, the meat was a little rough and lacking.  The scallops were ok, not enough to save the dish though.patatas bravas - spicy potatoes were flavorful, but not spicypaella - it took almost an hour for the paella to come out.  In fact we ordered the potatoes after the other dishes came out, and even that came out before the paella!  For that long of a wait it better have been the greatest paella ever, but alas it was mediocre.When finished we asked the waiter for dessert menus.  15 minutes later, nothing.  We flagged down a busser to retrieve menus, and he got them quickly.  We ordered the chocolate croquettes with banana marshmallows.  Pretty flat and disappointing, but it is a dish to try.  It was pretty busy for a Thursday night, but the service misfires were too much to overcome.  I hope others had a better experience than I did.  Skip.

Reviews.Author: Phillip C.
Reviews.Content: my friend comes from New York a few times a year and stays at the black stone. we eat here every morning. the first table next to the window on the left hand side. food is good, service is great, atmosphere is wonderful. i just wish they would change up the menu. it's been the same for over a year. we started coming here when I started college. there's never a morning special or a surprise. overall, i love my experience and i love being able to always sit at the same table.

Reviews.Author: Vivian Y.
Reviews.Content: If you come here, definitely opt for the $58 tasting menu. You'll be amazed how they can prepare 20 dishes and the variety for that price.  We had everything from cheese, to meatballs, shrimp, octopus, lamb, beef, butternut squash raviolis.....MMM....All the food was good, and about 4 were mind blowlingly good.  If you don't do the tasting, the head for the australian rack of lamb for sure!  it was delicious and perfectly prepared.Drinks are expensive. Cocktails are $11.50 and a pitcher of Sangria was $32.  Yes you can get more for your money at Babareeba or even Emilios, but you're paying for Michigan Ave and a MUCH nicer ambiance.  At the end of the night, each couple spent $250 on food and drinks.  I don't normally spend this kind of money on dinner but it was for a friend's birthday.Service - I think our server was a little overwhelmed - he was running around like a mad man and by the end of our dinner, he almost forgot about us it took about 20 mins to get a round of coffee at our table. If you enjoy Bailey's in your coffee - order one because they offer a very large glass of it.  oh, but watch out, coffee alone here is $3.95 (YIKES!)

Reviews.Author: Kelly S.
Reviews.Content: I popped in here for dinner with my dad around 8:30pm on a Thursday.  It was a 30 minute wait for a table, but we found a seat in the alcove in the upstairs bar... which serves the entire menu as well.I had continuously heard about the avocado 'margarita' here and could not wait to have one.  Oh. My. Goodness.  Sounds a bit odd, right?  I assure you it's the best darn margarita you will have... ever.  I easily could have had two more of these, but I restrained myself due to the impending early alarm the next morning.  El Bolero - Patron Reposado, Orange Liquor, Fresh Lime, Fresh Avocado  $11.   GET ONE.The tapas we savored:*Bacon Wrapped Dates Stuffed with Almonds - the hit of the meal, hands down.*Garlic Shrimp - OK.  We both agreed that we could have done without this one.*Flatbread - Beef Shortribs, Horseradish, Parmesan & Bacon.  Really good. A perfect filler if you have a large appetite.*Catalan Spinach, Raisins, Pine Nuts & Apples.  I wish my mom made spinach like this when I was a kid!  *Slow-Cooked Shortribs & Diver Scallops, Shaved Parmesan Artichokes.  The second hit of the meal.  Although, I AM a scallop addict.Service:  Our waiter was super friendly and efficient.  Our food came out in stages, but all very quickly.  We'd almost be finished with one plate when the next one would arrive.  Decor:  Red, black, tall ceilings, single light bulbs hanging from the trusses, a water feature under the stairs.  The loungey electronic music was a bit too loud, but it wasn't bothersome.Highly recommended for special occasions... or when you are looking to take an out of town guest to a restaurant with a big city feel.  Something they definitely cannot experience in their hometown.

Reviews.Author: Kyle H.
Reviews.Content: I'm never "in the know" but my partner in crime is all about trying new places and it's a great addition to my tired bag of (Nacho) tricks! Had Friday 8pm reservations for two and waited just long enough in the bar to order Sangrias and admire the updated 70's decor. We were seated in  2nd floor the "party room" looking over the main dining area and it was an amazing view and our room had nice decorating touches that really added to the experience.I had the Seasonal Sangria and it didn't knock my socks off so I ordered the Red Sangria later, and that was fabulous. Up there with the BEST! For Tapas we went with:Mixto- Chef's cheese selection of 3 cheesesCroquetes de Jamon- Serrano Ham CroquettesHigos con Almendras- Bacon Wrapped Figs w/Almonds (the Star of the show!)Tucino con Xerez- Pork Belly, Sherry Glaze , Green Apple & Truffle (the sauce and presentation was out of this world)Espinacas a la Catalana- Spinach w/raisins, pine nuts & applesThe waiter also recommended the Rabbit but we couldn't handle eating a li'l bunny, but he said it was great...The waiter was quite helpful, always attentive, and each server (I think we had 5 different people bring our food) was polite and informative!Yes, it's expensive for Tapas, which we're lucky to have plenty of in Chicago; but the atmosphere and food are worth it!

Reviews.Author: Kim J.
Reviews.Content: A friend and I had a fantastic dinner at Mercat a la Planxa last night!  We were in the mood for tapas, and Iberico honestly just doesn't really do it for me, so we figured we'd try somewhere new.  Our server was Jerry and he was fabulous.  He recommended a few things off of the menu based off of what we said we were in the mood for, let us spend as much time as we wanted just enjoying our food and ordering more, and was attentive but not obtrusive.  We started out with the seasonal sangria.  It involved chiles and cilantro, which sounds kind of bizarre, but it was wonderful.  It had a nice bite but was really refreshing.  We started out with the chef's cheese plate.  It comes with 3 different types of cheese - 1 with goat's milk, 1 with sheep's milk, and 1 with cow's milk.  Each of them also came with an accompanying sauce - in this case we had a peach jam, an apple jam, and a black olive caramel sauce.  I ended up using the jams on the accompanying bread and eating the cheeses alone, as they were quite good on their own.  Our next course was bacon-wrapped dates with almonds with a bit of blue cheese drizzled on top.  Oh.  My.  God.  These were phenomenal.  We tried to convince the server that we just wanted a bucket of those for the rest of our meal.  They're smoky and sweet and just melt in your mouth.  They were so good that we actually ordered a second order of them.  After that, we had the flatbread with shrimp, chorizo, and garbanzo bean puree.  Also surprisingly good with just a hint of garlic and butter.  Our next choice was the paella.  It was perfect - seafood and crunchy rice on a hot metal platter.  It's so easy to screw up paella, but they did a wonderful version here.  And my friend is from Miami - she knows good Paella and good seafood, and she raved about what we had here.  Our final dish was a dish of spinach, apples, nuts, and a few other things.  It was probably my least favorite of the night - it was nicely done, but the spinach seemed a bit overwhelmed by all the other flavors present.  All in all a wonderful addition to the tapas scene.  A bit pricey for my liking, but well worth the cash.

Reviews.Author: Mahsa T.
Reviews.Content: Wow. Best tapas I've had anywhere. Amazing flavors and elegant presentation. Each dish is a work of art. And each bite packs a punch. Portions are tiny but the taste more than makes up for it.  Bacon-wrapped dates stuffed with almonds--AMAZINGCatalan spinach, raisins, pine nuts, and apples--DELICIOUSFlatbread (porcini, Catalan sausage, garlic, manchego)--GREATDiver scallops--HEAVENLYGrilled calamari--DELECTABLEButternut squash dumplings over lamb ragout, mushroom, black truffle--MMMMMMChocolate croquettes on banana marshmallow with caramel and olive oil--!@%$&*#!How can I best describe the croquettes? Like a chocolate ball explosion in your mouth mixed with ooey gooey marshmallow.As I mentioned before, the portions are really tiny, even for tapas. My friends and I had worked up an appetite salsa dancing across the street at the Chicago Summer Dance Festival, so we were still a bit hungry at the end of our meal. I would recommend getting at least 3 dishes per person. And definitely try the sangria. My favorite was the white sangria (pear and grape), which had a great sweet taste. Our server Juan Carlos was friendly and attentive and guided us through the menu. The restaurant itself, located in the Blackstone Hotel, is beautifully decorated, sleek and modern, fun and cheerful, with large windows overlooking Grant Park. With such steep prices, I won't be a regular here, but Mercat is definitely worth trying at least once.

Reviews.Author: leyla a.
Reviews.Content: 3.5 stars.  I shave a 1/2 point for price.i'm tired so this may be my absolute shortest review.  I am going to number everything...1. I couldn't find the damn door.2. when I finally found the damn door, I couldn't find my way upstairs to the damn main dining room3. once i got upstairs, everything was fine4. I was a little surprised by how tall the ceilings were.  5. I neither liked or dislike the light bulb light fixtures hanging from the ceiling. 6. we ordered a bunch of small plates7. I liked the potatoe omlette8. I liked the wild striped bass9. I thought the cocktails were un-original10. I thought the service was pretty good, nothing special, but on par for a restaurant of this type11. I thought the desserts were mediocre12. I liked the cheese selection13. I thought it was very expensive.  We spent about $350 for 4 people (inclusive of tax/service) and we had 1 drink each an NO entrees, just small plates.14. I think if I went back, I could get a great meal for a lot less by ordering more efficiently.

Reviews.Author: Orack B.
Reviews.Content: Yea I ate here an yea I dropped a lot of money, but yea I ate over half the menu.  Me and my boy dropped in here for a casual dinner on a freezing January Saturday night.  It was late I might add and the place was loud, lively and packed with the standard look-at-me jackasses.  The space is huge and the music was, to my tastes, excelente!  Kind of Euro vibe; loungy, funky,etc...  Well, we started with some excellent charcuterria.  From there we moved to the prawns - probably the best thing we had that night, we ordered it three times over all told, briny and charred perfectly.  It was nice to have them served head-on because sucking the brains and head out was tasty!  The chibarones were charred nicely al planxa - their specialty - but lacked that last hit of salt...  The pork belly was swimming in some kind of glaze that overpowered everything on the plate and did not do the protein proper justice.  The rabbit was good, but again, drowned in butter and the whole foam thing is so played out!  The lamb chops, once again from the grill, were recommended and for good reason.  Cooked to perfection and a palette pleaser no doubt.  Patatas bravas - SmokeyCebollas Rellenas - CheesyAbsinthe - DreamyRed Wine - PerfectWhite Wine - RefreshingBeers - Standard GoodnessI'll be back... with $30 in my wallet!

Reviews.Author: Dennis S.
Reviews.Content: Another five-star experience.  But I dread trying to get a table on a Friday or Saturday night during the summer.We had another great experience at Mercat.  And this time the service moved up to 5-stars too.  On a Thursday evening, the place was packed.  So when warm summer nights arrive, it's going to be difficult to schedule a table here.  But I will!Key tapas we had:- Porcini and Catalan sausage flatbread, with roasted garlic and manchego cheese.  Outstanding.- Serrano ham & fig salad, with la Peral cheese, baby spinach, spiced almonds and sherry vinaigrette - terrific again.  I can't imagine coming here without ordering this dish, it's so good.- Wild mushrooms, confit potato, and shallots.  A perfect compliment to the other dishes.- Garlic shrimp.  Tasted great, but lost in the competition with the other dishes.- Pork belly with a cider glaze, green apples and truffle.  Delicious, not overcooked, just the way a simple pork belly dish should taste.We had a few other dishes - breads, olives, and a couple tasty but very small desserts.  Plus two bottles of Spanish Albarino white, a great Spanish Orobio red, and a few after dinner drinks.  It made for a perfect three hour visit with friends over wine and tapas.

Reviews.Author: Kathleen M.
Reviews.Content: This restaurant had me at a Catalan name! When I saw that there had been a Yelp event here I was:1.   Jealous and mad that  I hadn't been included, didn't they know I spent my Jr. year of college in Barcelona?  2. Bound and determined to come here myself!After reading the reviews we decided to make it our second Brunch Adventure Sunday.  Our only problem was the parking - there wasn't any signage to indicate that the valet was around the corner at the Blackstone Hotel so we had parked at the Hilton across the street, hoping for validation, alas, there was not.Once we were in the restaurant, we liked the airy look and feel of the place.  We had a great table and started with the Roasted Suckling pig buffet, yes and yum!  We enjoyed that with cheese plus juice and coffee.  We then had the melon and almond first course, both fabulous.  The second course of shrimp and eggs was even better - best Eggs Benedict of my life.  The third course wasn't my fave but my husband really liked the duck confit croissant french toast and the brussel sprouts.  I made up for it by tasting all the sweets on the buffet and the mini dark chocolate tarts were worth the trip alone.Our waiter was very earnest and we liked the laid back vibe.  Jody Weis came in and no one bothered him at all.  That must be such a relief to him after all the shouting, protesting and picketing he used to get, and that was from the police officers!  Everyone was very cool and interested in their own table companions. If Brunch is this fantastic, what must the other meals be like?  We shall come and find out.

Reviews.Author: Crystal N.
Reviews.Content: Bottomless Mimosas and Bloody Marys. Need I say more???Why yes I can!  How 'bout Duck Confit with a cherry reduction sauce?!??!  *dies*Seriously.  Get your ass to Mercat's Sunday Brunch IMMEDIATELY!On second thought, don't!  More food for me!

Reviews.Author: Jesse A.
Reviews.Content: Could Flatbread really be this good? Really? Never in my wildest imagination. Not at all. I had a fabulous meal at Mercat. The service was great -- attentive but not over the top, the decor is fun, and the food and drinks were spot on, top quality, and I'm a harsh judge of these things. We had the serrano ham and fig salad - top notch! and the seared scallops we received accidentally were fabulous too (I confess, we gobbled them up before they could realize their mistake...) .. and oh... the flatbread, as I said, was unexpectedly incredible, and the paella de mariscos was overloaded with seafood -- cooked very nicely, not chewy or canned silly stuff... and NOT overloaded with rice. Also, they have a great red wine selection, and we had the seasonal sangria, with mango, cilantro and chili -- mmmmmmmmm is all I can say to that. The other patrons at the restaurant left a little to be desired - snobs and whiners, at least, those sitting near us....

Reviews.Author: Andrea H.
Reviews.Content: Apparently all bets are off for lunch.  My friends had been raving about this place, so when my friend suggested it for lunch, I was definitely in.  I checked out the website before (very cute btw), so I knew that the menu was different, but I still thought I would have the chance to get a taste of what they are all about.The lunch menu is a pretty good deal, 3 courses for $18.  I started with my favorite, pimientos de padron.  My friend had the spanish omelette.  She enjoyed the omelette, but I was disappointed when my peppers came out smothered in a very heavy sauce.  They are great the way they are, why mess with 'em?For the second course, I tried the Australian sea bass.  My friend had the scallops.  Nothing too creative about either dish.  The sea bass, that I'd heard rave reviews about, was very fishy and smothered in another really heavy sauce.  The scallops were also fishy and more heavy sauce.  I'm starting to see a pattern here...For dessert, we tried both the crema catalana and the chocolate croquettes.  These were actually very good, but nothing special.I would really like to come back for dinner so that I can see what everyone's been raving about.  As for lunch, very disappointing, skip it.  Everything was drowned in mayonnaise-y sauces and you couldn't actually taste the food...or maybe that was the plan all along.

Reviews.Author: Sean D.
Reviews.Content: Another great addition to the South Loop.  Mercat offers Catalan tapas that are simply fantastic.The decor is very cool and fitting for this festive atmosphere.  The music is a little loud, but still bearable.The spanish cheese selection is impressive as is the wide range of meats offered in addition to the small plates.  Perhaps my favorite thing about this restaurant is the whole roasted suckling pig.  I am definitely making a return trip for the experience (you need to give 48 hours notice).

Reviews.Author: Jennifer Y.
Reviews.Content: Back for the first time in a while.  We booked dinner for 6 for my husband's birthday and were hoping for a very special night.  Service was beyond terrible.  Food rushed out at first, our table over crowded with old plates, no one picking them up etc.  In fact, we had to start clearing it ourselves and insisting that the army of people crowding the food on our table take them away.  Then we hit a food drought.  Nothing came out for what seemed forever, and again, we stared at a dirty table while no one came to check on us.  Final straw was that after we finished eating our main server was doing the Absinthe demo at the table next to us and again, NO ONE came to check on us.  We sat waiting for someone to see if we wanted dessert or after dinner drinks for so long that we decided to go elsewhere.  The food was not as good as remembered.  EVERYTHING had saffron aoli and was way too heavy handed.  The only good thing about the night was the lamb chops... and they really were amazing!  Our dinner for 6 people was $600!  Our server  did find time to add a 19% tip to our bill.  At this price point, that type of service is unforgivable.  At no point during the night was it acknowledged that it was a special occasion despite my calling several times to mention it.   We weren't looking for anything free, but just something to make it more than just a dinner out.  Dessert at Hot Chocolate made us all smile again and remember what awesome service could add to a night out.  We will NEVER dine with Mercat again.

Reviews.Author: Jeff G.
Reviews.Content: Went to Mercat last night, and any of the early reviews with criticism of staff, their silly headsets, and any other nonsense must be ignored.  They have smoothed out the kinks, and there was only one earpiece in evidence, on what I assume was their rail-thin manager.As background, I was in Barcelona with my wife and parents last summer, and we found some amazing places to spend our devalued currency.  From the classic Taller de Tapas to a new, fusion joint, Bar Lobo, we tried everything.  As a side note, I would not be surprised if the decor in Mercat was inspired by Bar Lobo -- my wife and I both noted some great similarities.That's just the tip of the iceberg.  We were four, the magical number where tapas is no longer a wasted effort, and you get to try a wider variety.  And what variety -- Jos Garces has maintained a very close relationship with traditional Catalan style and yet pushes the boundaries of those traditions with insightful, inspired plates.  We ordered ten or twelve plates to split between the four of us, and only one was a disappointment.  The samplings of cured meats from whoever serves as their charcuterie were excellent; the seafood was impeccably prepared, and the seasoning was outstanding on all the dishes.  We selected the Black Angus ribeye as our meat course (and I ate a full helping of morcilla just cuz I'm a greedy mug), and it did not disappoint: it was perfectly prepared.  Brilliant/standout dishes include: 1) Squid in Its Own Ink, a challenging dish, and when it comes to the table, your jaw will drop, but the flavors and textures are perhaps some of the finest I have ever had the privilege of experiencing and 2) Bacon-Wrapped Dates, which, beyond the fact that the strong flavors are so delicately balanced, comes draped in the most amazing cream sauce imaginable.  Note: the beloved classic staple, Patatas Bravas, fails to taste like anything but soft barbecue chips.  They are oversalted and under-imagined.  If Jos could read this review and know that I love what he does, but wish he made different potatoes, I'd be happy.Our server was enthusiastic, knowledgeable, and personable.  I cannot point to any missteps she or the service staff made.So, in all, this really deserves a 4.2 or 4.3, because of its nearly flawless execution on ambiance and food, with no notable bumps in service.

Reviews.Author: Jen R.
Reviews.Content: Oh sweet flatbreads, I would marry you and have your babies if I could.  Between the two flatbreads I got my greedy little hands on - the margherita one and the shortrib one -  my ass was in heaven.  To me they tasted fresh, different, and damn good.  The rest of the menu - I've gotta admit, I was a little wtf.  A lot of cool tasty looking variety, but def not cheap.  Since I'm a total pussy and the last person to try something new I stuck with the flatbreads, which of course didn't stop my fat ass from sampling everything else that came to the table.  It was all tasty as hell, I've gotta admit.  On the stupid fruity drink front I rocked their mojito, which was tasty tasty - but totally fucking weak.  Seriously, I downed two in minutes and I didn't even feel a buzz or remotely slutty - which equals fail on the drink front.  Especially when I blew $24 on the two of them.  And the entire time we kept having to turn away other people's food which was mistakenly brought to our table.  At first I thought damn, am I really ordering all this shit and can't remember anything - maybe those drinks were stronger than I thought.  But no, and of course they mistakenly brought some flatbreads - way to screw with my mind Mercat!  Anyways, totally dug our server, who was super knowledgable about the menu and was free with the good suggestions.  Next time I'm in the mood to satisfy my flatbread whore tendencies - this is where I'll be.

Reviews.Author: Nancy H.
Reviews.Content: Usually, at a "small plates" kind of place, I spend a lot of money for food that rarely impresses me.  At Mercat, the $58 chef's tasting menu consists of various plates off the regular menu, and there wasn't a dish I didn't like!  It is served family style, and they are conscious of how many people will be sharing these dishes, so that everyone gets 1-2 of each dish.  Yes, it was expensive, but I thoroughly enjoyed my meal, and I didn't leave hungry. Our menu:Cheese plate paired w/apple marmalade and sliced raw applesTomato & garlic bruschettaSpinach salad w/serrano ham & sherry vinaigrette (dressed just enough)Shellfish croquettes (IMO, was fried for too long because the crust overpowered the filling)Garlic shrimpPrawnsSpicy potatoes w/paprika aioli (I thought these were a little dry)Porcini & sausage flatbreadRabbit dumplings w/candied cherries (a favorite for some of my friends)Warm spinach w/raisins & pine nuts (nice light accompaniment to the meats)Rack of lamb (my favorite - very tender and very little game taste)RibeyeThe sauce pairings for both red meats were perfect.  However, I thought the shrimp & prawns were overly salted and not very innovative.  We also tried 2 desserts: the chocolate croquette with banana marshmallow and the "Crema Catalana" (figs with orange whipped cream (?) and a golf ball sized scoop of berry sorbet).  The latter was the most disappointing (a dining companion said it was like eating "air"), and the former was just ok.  Desserts don't seem to be their strong point.Mercat is suitable for medium-sized groups and intimate parties.  The smaller tables/booths are along the perimeter of the sunken main dining floor, and the larger tables are in the center.  There is a bar in the corner with high tables, which is appropriate for people gazing.

Reviews.Author: Shradha A.
Reviews.Content: You know the restaurants that are such a great experience that you have absolutely fond memories and recommend to others for their special occasions too? Yeah, not this one. One of my besties was in town just for one night from Calgary and she was celebrating a new job. I decided to try out Mercat, which is where I almost went for my birthday dinner this summer had Girl & the Goat not opened that same week! The ambiance is nice, although a little too brightly lit. The music was really good! The food was quite delectable, although nothing in particular was memorable. But the reason I'm not coming back here is the service! **Absolutely terrible service!** The guy was so busy flirting with a neighboring table of 5 girls all night that he couldn't care less to make sure our tapas had arrived at the table, our glasses of water were refilled or stop by to ask if we wanted to order dessert. He was exceptionally rude and threw around an attitude that had no place to be there. I completely disagree with all the Yelp Talk around the fact that service shouldn't be part of a review, only food should be. When you pay such premium prices, you're doing so for the experience and service is an integral part of that experience. How can a restaurant such as this not have better training for their staff and ensure stricter enforcement of warm and cordial behavior with guests. Server bad day or distractions notwithstanding.

Reviews.Author: Jeff S.
Reviews.Content: Another day, another celebrity chef's restaurant. I recently ventured over to Mercat a la Planxa with 3 others for my birthday, so I knew I would have the opportunity to try a lot of food.FOOD:Tomato bread for the table: basically like pico de gallo on top of buttery bread. Delicious and light, only the ends of it seemed to be at all greasy. Great way to start. I loved this so much.Pulpo con patatas: I love mollusks, they taste delicious. This dish had a lot of paprika in it, with some acid from what I would assume is lemon juice, which together combined for great flavor. I don't know if the potatoes really added anything as the dish itself wasn't very strongly flavored, and not at all salty. However, the octopus was awesome, and would strongly recommend this to anyone.Bacon wrapped dates: My friend told me a few different time about these dates - I'm not sure if it was because she didn't remember telling me about them, or if she just loved them so much. Well, it was probably the latter because these things were my favorite dish of the night. It was a classic sweet + savory combination that worked so well. Get these.Truita de patata: I was surprised at how much I liked this dish - very creamy, well seasoned, and not a lot of saltiness. All good things. I'm glad Chef Garces went with a goat cheese for this one - the subtle and soft flavor went really well with the creamy lentils.Albondigas de venera (scallop and shrimp meatballs): Some might not agree with mushing up scallops and shrimp into ball form, but I think it was genius. I like meat balls, I like seafood, I like this dish. Like scallopballs (not to be confused with scallop testes) with chunks of shrimp in it, if that makes sense.Serrano ham and fig salad: an't go to a Spanish restaurant without getting some of that jamon, right? The jamon de Iberico de bellato (or something like that, basically Iberico pork-belly ham) was a bit much on el dinero side, but we got this ham and fig salad based on a recommendation from a friend. Very good, although I didn't taste much fig until I went digging around looking for it. Serrano ham was delicious, albeit extraordinarily salty. I guess I'm more used to the more subtle flavor of proscuitto.Pinxtos muranos (lamb brochettes wrapped in bacon): Well, this was good. But bacon wrapped anything is good. One point here is that I didn't get much of a lamb taste. I hope this wasn't due to being two pitchers of sangria deep, but I felt like the lamb was overpowered by the bacon + sauce. Sauce was sweet btw.Paella valenciana (chicken & chorizo paella w/artichoke and tomato salad): I love paella. I usually like rice dishes. Good flavors (chorizo in here was great), but the chicken was pretty bland on its own. Probably a good thing considering that my salt sensing 'buds were in overdrive. I prefer paella del mar (I think I can speak el espanol, I really can't though), and I actually prefer Cafe Babareeba's paella to this one. However, I (we) was (were) really full at this point, so maybe that impacted what I tasted.DESSERT: Croquettes de xocolate (chocolate and caramel filled croquettes): So good. Deep fried balls filled with chocolate and caramel? YEA GIMME. Shove one of these with the banana cream into your fat face and wait for a gush of awesomeness and sweetness. There were 6 croquettes and 4 of us, I decided to grab two. Someone else was smart enough to grab the last one.SERVICE: Fast, friendly, and very helpful with recommendations. They also weren't very intrusive, but were around whenever one of us needed a refill or we needed some more sangria. Our server was also very personable and just fun.VALUE/OVERALL:I think that for a tapas place owned by an Iron Chef, Mercat is a pretty good overall value. It's more expensive than some of the other tapas places in the city, but not by much. Alot of it could be the inherently more expensive ingredients used in Chef Garces' menu. Overall, this was a great dinner. I'll definitely be back, if for nothing else but to get my hands on those dates again.

Reviews.Author: Amy H.
Reviews.Content: I don't know what it was that I didn't like at Mercat.  Maybe it was the limited variety of food.  Maybe was the way they served everything family style from a pre-set menu and you had no say in the what you were being fed.  Maybe it was because we had to flag down a server more times that we should have had to.  Something about our brunch just felt a bit off.  The food was decent and a good value for $25 (plus the bottomless mimosas or bloody mary bar will give you a nice zing were a mere $8 extra), but I really would have liked a few made-to-order options or had some input into what I was being served.  This brunch was also heavy on the lunch and light on the breakfast, which was disappointing to me.

Reviews.Author: kahee y.
Reviews.Content: saturday late dinner, 9:30, 6 friendsOh Jose Garces, WTF? having dined at a couple of his philadelphia restaurants, I really had high expectations for Mercat.  i would give this place ZERO stars if i could.  in comparison to his philadelphia restaurants.. i could not believe Mercat was one of his. food - The food was just NOT tasty, not one dish wowed us; it was all very.. boring. it was the biggest disappointment.   octopus fritters - um... ok, not really.  it tasted like straight up batterflash fried peppers - how is this on the menu? lifeless peppers with NO flavor, literally tasted like nothingpaella negra - the taste of the ink overpowered every other flavor in this dish, reminded me of nyc chinatown, yuck. and everyone's teeth turned black.  hot.brussels sprouts- id rather go to whole foods and buy a pound for $7.99cauliflower- finally a unique and flavorful dish, but beware, it's gross once it gets cold.  scallop over short-ribs- it's mayor bloomberg level salty.  oh my god i thought i was eating straight up salt.  the scallops were over-cooked.. greatpork belly - everyone in the industry is doing this.. how can it be so mediocre?  step it upbeef short-rib flatbread - eh..red wine sangria - if watered down red punch is your thing.. go for it.service - in a huge space with high ceilings and chatter everywhere, not one person in our party heard our server say anything.  and being a tapas place, you would think they would announce each dish as it is being served.. nope.  i had to request every time for the name.  and our sangria came out after our first couple dishes... um...  ????would i go back - hell effin NO!

Reviews.Author: Dan D.
Reviews.Content: I went here for Valentine's Day and had quite possibly one of the best meals I've had for many months. Having lived in Barcelona for a period, I am quite familiar with Spanish food and tapas. Mercat a La Planxa does not serve your typical tapas menu. Rather, they take the Barcelona food, and place a very unique spin to the classic dish. Each dish has a wonderful taste and makes you wonder -- "just what else did they add to this to make it soo darn good?!"Seafood is important for Barcelona cuisine as it is at this restaurant. The grilled shrimp prawns were superb! Not doused in sauce, but spiced just right and laid right on the plate. The beef entrees are a real treat as well (although not truly a common Catalan staple, but they do it wonderfully). Fillets are cooked just like a great steakhouse. Come here to try a new Spanish-style restaurant. Leave here knowing you ate amazing food with great modern flair to old spain-classics!

Reviews.Author: T O.
Reviews.Content: Great food, great service, excellent wine choices, yummy cocktails. Every time I'm in Chicago I stop here.

Reviews.Author: Slu S.
Reviews.Content: This place is what tapas should be everywhere. I went with high expectations and they were certainly met. If nothing else, the lunch that Garces puts on is better than most anywhere in the loop area.We ate the mixto of queso which included Cado Urgelia (cow's cheese with apple and lavender), Gorrotxa (goat's cheese with garlic and dulce de leche), and Ombra (sheep's cheese with orange marmelade). Then I moved on to the Serrano and Fig salad. This salad was completely awesome. The salty serrano and the sweet fig worked so well together. Wild mushrooms and shallots were up next. They were great, but I was getting filled up by this point.We finished with the chocolate souffle that was spectacular. One of the best desserts in the loop. Perfect with a little sherry.I look forward to coming back to try the entire pig.

Reviews.Author: Sabrina M.
Reviews.Content: Went back here last night for a friend's birthday and am happy to report that they seem to have resolved their service issues. That, and the food, are the only reasons I'm giving it an extra star from the first visit. But I still wasn't blown away by this place.I can't put my finger on it but something's...off. The food being delicious is not the issue. My friends and I feasted on scallops (outstanding), dates wrapped in bacon, gambas al ajillo, paella, duck (also outstanding). But there's just some kind of disconnect with this place. It wants to be upscale and charges upscale prices to be sure. But it is not consistently outstanding. The servers all wear uniforms, but then the guy who actually delivers the food to the table is wearing jeans and looks like a bum.All of our backs were hurting by the end of dinner because the wooden chairs are so blasted uncomfortable. It took forever to get our duck but it was very good. There's a certain charm, a certain warmth, a certain consistency that's just lacking. This experience was definitely better than when I went for my birthday, but Mercat is still not a destination spot for me in the neighborhood.

Reviews.Author: Janet E.
Reviews.Content: We came here for dinner and my stomach and my wallet both left empty after leaving this restaurant.The food: Four stars for flavorThe portions: Two starsThe price: Two starsThe service: Four starsI know tapas are small plates, but this was ridiculously small. We shared our tapas between two people and ended up with one bite per person!We started off with the complimentary garlic and tomato bread. It was delicious.  The biggest portioned dish out of our entire meal!Next was the bacon wrapped dates.  Total four dates, two per skewer. Flavor was excellent.We continued on with the Shellfish Croquettes.  Five little tiny shellfish on top of a bed of rice. Surprisingly, this was very good. It was something in the rice.... We then tried the butternut squash dumplings. These were OUTSTANDING!!! My favorite dish of the night! There was only three small pieces!!!! I wish there were more....For substance, we ate the shrimp, chorizo, and garbanzo bean puree flatbread. I made sure to drink lots of water, hoping this would expand and fill my stomach! To end, we ordered a cake with plum sauce and almond ice cream. It was the least memorable part of our meal. Four tapas, one dessert, and one martini was over $80. After we left, I wanted to hit up Dairy Queen for some dinner.One last thing....make sure to head upstairs for the restaurant. The bar is at the bottom and there is a podium that looks like a hostess should be standing there, but no one will ever come. We stood there for a while and no one attended to us.

Reviews.Author: Ramya P.
Reviews.Content: TRUFFLE EXPLOSION!!Being fans of the Iron chef, me and the hubby decided to have a date night here recently and made our reservations for an early dinner. While my husband was parking the car (easy to find space on Wabash) I ordered a mocktail of the bartender's choice and she gave a me a refreshing concoction not listed on the menu. After the two of us were seated, our gracious waiter explained the various options for us vegetarians. He explained that the chefs would be excited to please diners with dietary restrictions and make dishes that were not listed on the menu, if we got the Chef's tasting menu. We were convinced and then it began, three courses of delectable tapas designed to please the palate. First course : 1. Laperal cheese and bread with Apricot cider mustard (YUM!)2. A simple frisee salad with asparagus and tomatoes dressed generously in a vinaigrette3. An assortment of imported olives4. Frittata with spinach, potatoes and saffron aoili 5. And a dish that reminded us of a bruschetta.Second course:Included all the dishes mentioned in their Verduras (vegetables category)Third course:1. Risotto like dish with cauliflowers2. Assorted mushrooms roasted with potato confit and truffle oil3. Butternut squash dumplings 4. Flat-bread with mushrooms and truffle Its a LOT of food...So, go hungry and you will be impressed!!

Reviews.Author: Shazza B.
Reviews.Content: YUCK. This place was really rather awful. The plating was absurd and overly dramatic. The way my "salad" was served was pretentious, and inedible ... Don't bother

Reviews.Author: Rachelle B.
Reviews.Content: I met up with two friends for dinner at Mercat a la Planxa, Chicago's only Catalan restaurant, on South Michigan Avenue. I was up on North Michigan between work and dinner and I thought "oh, I'll just walk down for dinner." Right. That's a long walk from Chicago Avenue. I ended up arriving wet from the rain, blistered from my shoes, hot, late, and frazzled. My friends were having drinks in the bar and I joined them for one before we headed up for dinner. Nothing like booze to calm the nerves.Mercat a la Planxa's bar is on the first floor, street level. The dining room is one floor up. I didn't realize beforehand that the restaurant is located in the Blackstone Hotel. The interior is really beautiful. Warm colors. Modern touches. I thought it was cool how the kitchen is wide open, making it almost part of the decor, a show of the process.Chef Jose Garces is the the owner of Mercat a la Planxa. I'd heard of him from the Food Network, where he won the Next Iron Chef challenge. Think what you like about the Food Network and it's challenges, but Chef Garces also won the James Beard Award for best mid-atlantic chef.Our waitress that night was a firecracker. And really good at her job. Funny, but not trying too hard. Friendly. And she knew her stuff too. She mentioned to us that Chef Jose Garces was in the kitchen.
